description: The Bridge of Peace is a stunning bow-shaped pedestrian bridge spanning 150 meters over the Kura River in central Tbilisi. Designed by Italian architect Michele De Lucchi and inaugurated in 2010, this steel and glass structure connects the historic Old Town with the modern Rike Park district. The bridge features a futuristic canopy illuminated by over 10,000 LED lights that display an interactive light show every evening, transmitting a profound message in Morse code about human unity.
highlights: 150-meter bow-shaped steel and glass pedestrian bridge designed by renowned Italian architect Michele De Lucchi
Over 10,000 LED lights (1,208 custom LED fixtures) creating an interactive light display that activates 90 minutes before sunset
Unique Morse code message transmitted by pulsating LEDs displaying chemical elements from Mendeleev's periodic table found in the human body
240 motion sensors embedded in glass railings that trigger LED arrays as pedestrians pass, creating personalized lighting effects
Panoramic views of Old Tbilisi, Narikala Fortress, Metekhi Church, and the Kura River from the bridge walkway
French lighting designer Philippe Martinaud's masterful illumination concept symbolizing 'the anthem of life and peace among people and nations'
Architectural design reminiscent of a marine animal with a curvy transparent canopy
Strategic connection point between Tbilisi's historical past (Old Town) and contemporary future (new districts)
tips: Visit both during daytime to appreciate the architectural details and in the evening for the mesmerizing LED light show (lights activate 90 minutes before sunset)
Bring your camera or smartphone - the bridge is extremely photogenic, especially at sunset and after dark when the LED display is active
The Morse code message displaying periodic table elements repeats every hour across the two parapets - watch for the complete sequence
Wear comfortable walking shoes as you'll likely explore surrounding areas; old Tbilisi streets can be uneven
Exercise caution during rainy weather as the glass surface can become slippery
Allocate about 1 hour to fully explore the bridge and immediate surroundings
Bring some cash for street vendors near the bridge who may not accept cards
Best months to visit are April to June and September to October for pleasant weather
The bridge is open 24/7 with no entrance fee - completely free to access
Combine your visit with nearby attractions: Rike Park, Narikala Fortress, Metekhi Church, and the sulfur baths district
For best photography, capture shots just after sunset when the bridge lights up beautifully against the darkening sky
Walk slowly to trigger the motion sensors in the railings and experience the personalized lighting effect
vibe: Contemporary and futuristic yet symbolic - the Bridge of Peace represents Tbilisi's bold embrace of modern architecture while carrying a deeply humanistic message. The atmosphere transforms dramatically from day to night: during daylight, it's a sleek, functional pedestrian crossing offering spectacular views; after dark, it becomes a glowing, ethereal art installation. The bridge evokes wonder and contemplation as its LED lights pulse with scientific symbolism, reminding visitors that despite our differences, all humans share the same chemical composition. The setting creates a unique juxtaposition between the ancient stone architecture of Old Tbilisi and Georgia's forward-looking aspirations, making it feel like a portal between two different eras of the city's identity.
expectations: A peaceful, romantic pedestrian bridge perfect for evening strolls with beautiful lighting
Seamless integration with Tbilisi's historic architecture and urban fabric
Universal acclaim from locals as a beloved landmark
A quiet, contemplative space focused on the symbolic Morse code message
Traditional Georgian architectural elements blended with modern design
reality: The bridge is indeed spectacular at night, but also crowded with tourists, street performers, and photographers - it's a bustling attraction rather than a tranquil escape
The ultramodern glass and steel design is deliberately provocative and stands in stark contrast to the historic old town - it doesn't try to blend in

The bridge remains controversial among locals even today; many residents criticize it as too extravagant and out of place in the historical district, earning it the sardonic nickname 'Always Ultra bridge' due to its shape
Most visitors don't realize the LED lights are transmitting a Morse code message about periodic table elements - the symbolic meaning is lost on many who simply enjoy the pretty lights
The bridge serves as a highly functional daily pedestrian crossing for locals commuting between districts, not just a tourist attraction
The structure was built entirely in Italy and shipped to Tbilisi in 200 trucks - it's an imported design rather than a Georgian creation
While stunning, some visitors find it doesn't warrant a special trip - it's best experienced while already exploring the riverside area
The bridge represents broader tensions in Tbilisi about modernization versus historic preservation, making it a politically charged landmark
unique_facts: The entire bridge structure was fabricated in Italy and transported to Tbilisi in 200 trucks, with lighting installed on-site during assembly in 2009-2010
Construction cost 12.5 million GEL (approximately 7.5 million USD) - considered extravagant by many critics given Georgia's economic situation at the time
Architect Michele De Lucchi also designed other prominent Tbilisi buildings including the Ceremonial Palace of Georgia and the Ministry of Internal Affairs
The LED Morse code message displays only the chemical elements from Mendeleev's periodic table that are present in the human body - a scientific poetry symbolizing universal human unity
The bridge features 240 motion sensors that create an interactive experience, lighting up the glass railings as individual pedestrians pass by
Opening ceremony took place on May 6, 2010, commissioned by then-President Mikheil Saakashvili as part of his modernization campaign
The bridge's design inspiration came from marine life - its curved form resembles a sea creature or aquatic organism
Critics among opposition politicians, architects, and urban planners complained the bridge 'unduly dominated' historical landmarks and disrupted the Old Town's aesthetic coherence
Despite controversy, the bridge has become one of Tbilisi's most photographed landmarks and features prominently in tourism marketing materials
The bridge connects two symbolic zones: Old Tbilisi (representing Georgia's ancient heritage) and Rike Park (representing contemporary development)

French lighting designer Philippe Martinaud called the LED message 'an anthem of life and peace among people and peoples,' emphasizing that all humans are made of the same elements regardless of nationality or background
The 1,208 custom LED fixtures activate automatically 90 minutes before sunset every day, creating a synchronized light show visible across the city
surprises: The bridge is far more controversial among Tbilisi residents than tourists might expect - many locals view it as a symbol of inappropriate modernization and government excess
The profound Morse code message about human unity through shared chemical elements goes largely unnoticed by most visitors who simply see flashing lights
The bridge has become a political statement as much as an architectural one, representing tensions between tradition and progress in Georgian society
The nickname 'Always Ultra bridge' (comparing it to feminine hygiene products) reveals how some locals use humor to express their discontent with the design
Despite being criticized as 'out of place,' the bridge has significantly increased tourism to the area and become an iconic symbol of Tbilisi internationally
The motion-sensor lighting system creates a personalized experience for each pedestrian, making you feel like the bridge is responding specifically to your presence
The glass and steel structure actually enhances views of historic landmarks rather than obscuring them - it frames the old city in unexpected ways
The bridge functions as a vital pedestrian link for daily commuters, not just a tourist attraction - it serves a genuine urban infrastructure purpose
Cultural conservationists' concerns about disrupting traditional charm have proven somewhat unfounded - many visitors feel the contrast between old and new actually enhances both
The bridge looks dramatically different from various vantage points around the city, creating multiple distinct photographic opportunities depending on where you view it from
